content.webTitle: Bricking it: Bake Off judges reject Guardian reporter's rock-hard brownies

fields.headline: Bricking it: Bake Off judges reject Guardian reporter's rock-hard brownies
fields.bodyText: “Never bake again” is Paul Hollywood’s advice for me when I present him and Prue Leith with a tray of mediocre, hard brownies that have been left in the oven for too long. After failing to cut into them, the veteran Great British Bake Off judge rises from his seat, stacks my desserts on the floor and steps on them to prove that even a boot would fall short of dismantling them. It seems a tad harsh, even for a man known for his steely looks and severe put-downs on screen. But Hollywood is not one for pulling punches when it comes to his culinary criticism, and he has strong words for those who questioned his decision to remain with GBBO after Channel 4 controversially poached the programme from the BBC last year. “I question those who have criticised me for staying with Bake Off,” Hollywood says from the set in Welford Park in Berkshire on a rainy afternoon in mid-July. “I’ve just stuck with my job, because I love it. Why would I leave my job? It’s everyone else who has left.” Channel 4 will air the highly anticipated first episode of the The Great British Bake Off on 29 August. With 14 million viewers watching its most recent final, the show’s relocation prompted a backlash from fans and members of the cast. Presenters Sue Perkins and Mel Giedroyc cut ties with the show, as did Hollywood’s co-judge and national treasure, Mary Berry, who is returning to her role as a judge on a new BBC cooking programme. In their place, Channel 4 has brought on Prue Leith as a judge and Noel Fielding and Sandi Toksvig as presenters. The programme is still based at Welford Park, the country house and private estate, famous for its display of snowdrops, and once used by King Henry VIII as his personal hunting lodge. Welford Park has been the site of the Bake Off tent for the past four years. But for the first time, producers have opened the doors to newspaper journalists, who have the opportunity to have their baking critiqued by Hollywood and Leith. The cabbie who drove me to the site from Newbury told me he was strictly forbidden from talking about the show, and that all the taxi drivers who took people to the location had to sign a contract. “I find it quite amusing,” he said, joking that I would probably have to produce my fingerprints on arrival. While I didn’t have to do that, I was required to sign a non-disclosure agreement and refrain from taking any pictures or tweeting about the day. The machinations of Bake Off, it appears, are as classified as those of Area 51, and one producer quipped that whenever she brings family and friends to the set, it feels “a bit like they’ve won the golden ticket to see Willy Wonka”. With this air of mystery, can viewers expect a different show to the one they have grown accustomed to? “We’ve got different hosts and a different judge, that’s the only difference,” Hollywood says. “The feel of the show is exactly the same as it’s always been. “Once people watch it they’ll understand that the format is what it’s all about. The main picture has always been the bakers, and the standard has been borderline professional this year.” “I really think if you give it one minute’s thought,” Leith says, “Channel 4 paid a lot of money for a product: they’re not then going to change that product, they’re buying what was hugely successful.” Last month, Channel 4 boss, Jay Hunt, suggested the new series would be given a “modern” revamp, and Fielding and Toksvig are expected to help deliver this. “I think if you put Noel Fielding into a show, he’s going to make it a bit cool,” Leith says. “Modernisation is probably the wrong word,” Hollywood says. “There’s a change in dynamics with Noel and Sandy, because they’re not Mel and Sue, who have been together for 150 years or something. Noel and Sandy’s comedy is different to theirs. But it’s really funny, and together it’s hilarious because it’s so starkly different.” And do Hollywood and Leith share a chemistry and sense of humour? “It feels like I’ve been working with Prue for years. She reminds me of my mother-in-law, in a good way,” he says. “We met at one of the tests, and as soon as we started chatting, in my head I went, ‘yep, that’s it’.” “We both laugh at the same things, but Paul is wicked,” Prue says. “I mean, he is absolutely wicked. When I was really nervous on the very first day, I walked into the tent, and we had to learn the names of 12 people we’d never clapped eyes on. I couldn’t remember one contestant’s name. I asked Paul, ‘that’s Harry, isn’t it?’ He said, ‘no, that’s Tom.’ So I said, ‘Tom, tell us about your signature bake,’ and everyone laughed. Cut. He was lying and landed me bang in it. I thought, ‘okay, I’ve got your measure.’” Though she was brought on to replace Berry, Leith, cool and collected, explains she feels no pressure about having to step into her predecessor’s shoes. “I’m not trying to be Mary. She stood there, tasted the cakes, said what she thought about it – I do exactly the same. It’s just that I have a different personality … Presumably they hired me because they think I can do the job. I’m doing the job, I’m enjoying it – I don’t feel it’s going wrong.” While praising the “strongest characters” in the show’s history, the judges refuse to pick a favourite, claiming the only thing that will impress them is what’s on the plate. “We won’t remember your face but we’ll remember your brownies,” Leith says in a further vote of confidence. Past contestants, she says, “all hugely admire Paul, and I’ve noticed that some of them will still text him if they need help or advice.” “What? The bakers here, text me? When?” Hollywood asks in horror, before saying: “Nadiya [Hussain] texted me and said, ‘are you going to a demo this weekend?’ Candice [Brown] texted because I got a copy of her new book, which I thought was amazing. Nancy [Birtwhistle] came on my tour, she’d just won by about two months, so she texts me occasionally. Prue is making out like the bakers here text me: it’s certainly not every day.” So no WhatsApp thread? “No,” he says. “I don’t message them going, ‘hi guys, how are you getting on today, you winners?’” Leith comes to the rescue. “What I meant is Paul has this exterior of being tough as old boots, but ask him for some help and he’ll give it to you,” she says. “I am sure there are past bakers who feel that their career has been helped by him.” Unfortunately, it seems there won’t be any help for my baking career. Even though I make my excuses – “I’ve only baked twice before” and “it was short notice” – Hollywood is having none of it. The only sage words of advice are that they could always use me on set as a handyman and my brownies as bricks.
